[[Anniston, Alabama|Anniston]], [[Alabama]], [[United States]] | death_date = | instrument = [[Harmonica]], [[Human voice|vocals]], [[piano]], [[guitar]], [[drum kit|drums]] | genre = [[Blues]] | occupation = [[List of harmonicists|Harmonicist]], [[singing|singer]], [[songwriter]] | years_active = 1970s-present | label = [[Black Top Records|Black Top]], various | associated_acts = | website = }} '''James Harman''' (born June 8, 1946, [[Anniston, Alabama]], [[United States]]) is an [[United States|American]] [[blues]] [[harmonica]] player, [[singing|singer]], and [[songwriter]].{{cite web|author=[[Cub Koda]] |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/james-harman-mn0000149939/biography |title=James Harman | Biography |publisher=AllMusic |date=1946-06-08 |accessdate=2014-01-26}} [[music journalism|Music journalist]] Tony Russell described Harman as an "amusing songwriter and an excellent, unfussy [[blues harp]] player". ==Biography== Born '''Leslie James Harman''', at the age of four, Harman began lessons in [[piano]] playing, and also sang in his local [[church choir]]. Harmonicas owned by his father were stored in the piano bench, and James tried playing them after his piano lessons ended. In time, he became capable in several other [[musical instruments]], including [[guitar]], [[electric organ]], and [[drum]]s.{{cite web|url=http://www.jamesharman.com/bio.htm |title=Bio |publisher=James Harman |date= |accessdate=2014-01-26}} In 1962 he relocated to [[Panama City, Florida|Panama City]], Florida, where he played in many [[rhythm and blues]] [[musical ensemble|bands]], of which The Icehouse Blues Band was the last. [[Earl Caldwell]], manager of [[The Swinging Medallions]], signed Harman to a [[recording contract]]. In 1964 in [[Atlanta]], Georgia, Harman recorded the first of nine early [[single (music)|singles]], which were variously released on five different [[record label]]s. Harman performed as a blues harmonica player and singer in [[Chicago]], [[New York]], and elsewhere before moving to [[southern California]] in the 1970s.{{cite book | first= Tony | last= Russell| year= 1997 | title= The Blues: From Robert Johnson to Robert Cray | publisher= Carlton Books Limited | location= Dubai | page= 116| isbn= 1-85868-255-X}} There, his Icehouse Blues Band played alongside [[Big Joe Turner]], [[John Lee Hooker]], [[Freddie King]], [[Muddy Waters]], [[Albert King]], [[B. B. King]], [[T-Bone Walker]], [[Lowell Fulsom]], [[Eddie "Cleanhead" Vinson]], [[Johnny "Guitar" Watson]], and [[Albert Collins]]. In 1977 he formed the James Harman Band. Over the years their line-up has included [[Phil Alvin]] and Bill Bateman, who left in 1978 to form [[The Blasters]]; [[Gene Taylor (pianist)|Gene Taylor]], who departed in 1981, also to join the Blasters before moving on to [[The Fabulous Thunderbirds]]; and [[Kid Ramos]]. Alumni also included the late [[Hollywood Fats]] who, after leaving his own band in 1980, played alongside Harman for five years. Harman became known as a skilled, reliable musician, whether for a backing band or leading his own ensemble. His band recorded several albums during the 1980s, before settling in 1990 at [[Black Top Records]]. Numerous Harman songs have been used in [[film]]s and on television, including "Kiss of Fire" (from ''Those Dangerous Gentlemen''), which was on the [[soundtrack]] of ''[[The Accused (1988 film)|The Accused]]''. Harman has received several [[Blues Music Award|W. C. Handy Blues Award]] nominations, for songs on his own releases and on other artists' albums. He has been inducted into the [[Alabama Music Hall of Fame]] and received the "Best Blues Album of the Year" award from the ''Real Blues'' magazine. In 1995 Harman recorded a song named for the [[Zoo Bar (Lincoln, Nebraska)|Zoo Bar]] [[nightclub|club]] in [[Lincoln, Nebraska|Lincoln]], [[Nebraska]].{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/black-white-mw0000178900 |title=Black & White - James Harman,James Harman Band,The James Harman Band | Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-26}} "Everybody's Rockin' (At The Zoo Bar)" can be found on Harman's ''Black & White'' album.{{cite web|title=''Black & White'' by James Harman|url=http://www.amazon.com/Black-White-James-Harman/dp/B000007QBO|publisher=[[Amazon.com]]|accessdate=6 July 2013}} Harman has also performed at the [[Long Beach Blues Festival]], and around the world in concert. In 2003 Harman appeared on the [[ZZ Top]] album ''[[Mescalero (album)|Mescalero]]'', on the song "Que Lastima" and, in 2012, on ''[[La Futura]]'',{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/la-futura-mw0002411672/credits |title=La Futura - ZZ Top | Credits |publisher=AllMusic |date=2012-09-11 |accessdate=2013-08-14}} on the song "Heartache In Blue". ==Discography== * ''Those Dangerous Gentlemen'' – [[Rhino Records|Rhino]] (1987) * ''Extra Napkins'' – Rivera Records (1988) * ''Strictly Live...
